patches.instructions:
How to Install the Hotfix

Please read carefully the instructions before proceed.

Procedure to migrate :

  • 1. Remove the following jars from webapps\ROOT\WEB-INF\lib\
    • a. jahia-gwt-*.jar
    • b. jahia-impl-*.jar
    • c. jahia-taglib-*.jar
  • 2. Copy the content of the output folder into your webapps\ROOT\ folder
  • 3. Launch Jahia

How to Install the Hotfix

Please read carefully the instructions before proceed.

Procedure to migrate :

  • 1. Remove the following jars from webapps\ROOT\WEB-INF\lib\
    • a. jahia-gwt-*.jar
    • b. jahia-impl-*.jar
    • c. jahia-taglib-*.jar
  • 2. Copy the content of the output folder into your webapps\ROOT\ folder
  • 3. Launch Jahia

How to Install the Hotfix

Please read carefully the instructions before proceed.

Procedure to migrate :

  • 1. Remove the following jars from webapps\ROOT\WEB-INF\lib\
    • a. jahia-gwt-*.jar
    • b. jahia-impl-*.jar
    • c. jahia-taglib-*.jar
    • d. jackrabbit-core-ext-*.
  • 2. Modify the following configuration file:
    • * UnixDiff_applicationcontext-hibernate_xml.txt for WEB-INF\etc\spring\applicationcontext-hibernate.xml
    • * UnixDiff_Applicationcontext-services_xml.txt for WEB-INF\etc\spring\applicationcontext-services.xml
    • * UnixDiff_JahiaInternalResources_properties.txt for WEB-INF\classes\JahiaInternalResources.properties
    • * UnixDiff_JahiaInternalTypes_properties.txt for WEB-INF\classes\JahiaTypesResources.properties
  • 3. Copy the content of the output folder into your webapps\ROOT\ folder
  • 4. Launch Jahia

Please: 

  • Stop jahia before backing up and running the fix applier
  • Backup your jahia installation before running the fix applier
  • Run a pre-production test first

Step 1 : Jahia Core Migration

The first step of the migration is to copy the fix applier Jahia6.5_6.5.1.0_to_6.5.1.1.jar to your production server

At this stage, a list of all the files you have customized in your installation will help you to go through the upgrade and decide more easily if you want to merge, keep or overwrite the files.

Open a terminal in the JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/ROOT and type the following command :

java -jar <Jahia6.5_6.5.1.0_to_6.5.1.1.jar location>.

example for Linux user:

pwd : /home/jahia/
cd JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/ROOT
java -jar /home/jahia/Jahia6.5_6.5.1.0_to_6.5.1.1.jar

example for Windows user :

dir : C:\Users\jahia>
cd JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/ROOT
java -jar C:\Users\jahia\Jahia6.5_6.5.1.0_to_6.5.1.1.jar
 

The fix applier will manage the upgrade of your platform by deleting, updating and merging all the necessaries files.


For all the files impacted, the fix applier will create a backup in the following folder $USER_HOME/.fixapplier/backup/ and a detailed log is also available in your <Jahia_installation>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/META-INF/updates/history/fixes/Jahia6.5_6.5.1.0_to_6.5.1.1.log

Here is a log sample for the deletion part:

2011-09-07 13:19:27.964> Backed up existing directory to /home/jahia/.fixapplier/backup/Jahia6.56.5.1.0_6.5.1.1/gwt...
2011-09-07 13:19:28.048> Deleted /home/jahia/Builds/Website/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/gwt
2011-09-07 13:19:28.09> Backed up existing file to /home/jahia/.fixapplier/backup/Jahia6.56.5.1.0_6.5.1.1/modules/assets/javascript/ckeditor/LICENSE.jahia.txt...
2011-09-07 13:19:28.09> Deleted /home/jahia/Builds/Website/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/modules/assets/javascript/ckeditor/LICENSE.jahia.txt

If the fix creator detect that a file has been modified it will try to automatically merge it.

  • If the merge fails you will be able to overwrite the files or skip it installing the modification 
     
  • If you decide to skip it, a diff file <file_name>.patch will be available in the destination folder, so make sure that you don't forget to manually apply the changes.

Here is a log sample for the files update and automatic merging:

2011-09-07 13:27:17.339> Error: Checksum not equal on text file /home/jahia/Builds/Website/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/modules/facets/jnt_facets/html/facetDisplay.jspf, attempting automatic merging...
2011-09-07 13:27:17.341> Backed up existing file to /home/jahia/.fixapplier/backup/Jahia6.56.5.1.0_6.5.1.1/modules/facets/jnt_facets/html/facetDisplay.jspf...
2011-09-07 13:27:17.342> Patch succeeded, saving merge result to /home/jahia/Builds/Website/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/modules/facets/jnt_facets/html/facetDisplay.jspf

For all the properties files the fix applier lets you decide if you want to try to merge it automatically.

If the merge fails a diff file <file_name>.patch will be available in the destination folder, so make sure that you don't forget to manually apply the changes.

Here is a log sample for the properties files

Do you want to automatically merge file WEB-INF/etc/config/jahia.advanced.properties (Y)es/(N)o/(A)ll/n(O)ne ? 

2011-09-07 13:33:26.829> Backed up existing file to /home/jahia/.fixapplier/backup/Jahia6.56.5.1.0_6.5.1.1/WEB-INF/etc/config/jahia.advanced.properties...
2011-09-07 13:33:26.83> Applying patch /home/jahia/.fixapplier/temp/merge/WEB-INF/etc/config/jahia.advanced.properties.patch to file /home/jahia/Builds/Website/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/WEB-INF/etc/config/jahia.advanced.properties...

You can find all the operations made by the fix applier in the following files

<Jahia_installation>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/META-INF/updates/history/fixes/Jahia6.5_6.5.1.0_to_6.5.1.1.* 

Please review your log before starting the next step to ensure you haven't missed a file that needs to be manually merged.

Clean your Tomcat folder

Remove your folder JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/temp and JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/work

Step 2 : Jahia Administration

START JAHIA

Caches

Please, flush all caches of your Jahia server

Your upgrade to Jahia 6.5.1.1 is now completed

Please:

  • Stop the user requests / traffic to the server (either on the front-end Apache HTTPD server or firewall/router)
  • Stop Jahia before backing up and running the fix applier
  • Backup your Jahia installation before running the fix applier
  • Run a pre-production test first

For a standalone installation

Step 1:Jahia Core & Modules Migration

The first step of the migration is to copy the fix applier on your production server.

At this stage, a list of all the files you have customized in your installation will help you to go through the upgrade and decide more easily if you want to merge, keep or overwrite the files.

For all the files impacted, the fix applier will create a backup in the following folder:

$USER_HOME/.fixapplier/backup/ and a detailed log is also available in your <Jahia_installation>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/META-INF/updates/history/fixes/[PATCH].log or if you didn't use the default ROOT context in your <Jahia_installation>/tomcat/webapps/<your context>/META-INF/updates/history/fixes/[PATCH].log

If the fix creator detects that a file has been modified it will try to automatically merge it. If the merge fails you will be able to overwrite the files or skip it installing the modification. If the merge fails or you decide to skip it, a diff file <file_name>.patch will be available in the destination folder, please make sure that you don't forget to manually apply the changes.

1. Stop Jahia

2. Open a terminal in the JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/ROOT or JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/<your context> if you didn't use the default ROOT context  and type the following command:

java -jar <PATH-TO-FIX-APPLIER>/[PATCH].jar

The fix applier will manage the upgrade of your platform by deleting, updating and merging all the necessary files. It will now handles the migration of Jahia Core and all the additional Jahia modules installed on your platform.

In case you have externalized your configuration (jar file or folder), you will need to apply the modification relative to jahia.properties and jahia.advanced.properties manually at the appropriate place.

Please review your log before starting the next step to ensure you haven't missed a file that needs to be manually merged.

3. Clean the following Tomcat folder

The fix applier now handles the cleaning of the tomcat folders automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

Remove the content of your folders <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/temp and <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/work

4. Clean the ressource folder

Starting from 6.6.2.2  fix applier handles the cleaning of the /webapps/<your context>/resources folder automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

Remove the content of your folder  <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/resources or <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/webapps/<your context>/resources if you didn't use the default ROOT context.

5. Update your license.xml file

You will need to update your license key in the WEB-INF/etc/config folder. If you have externalized your configuration, you need to update the license key in the jahia-config.jar or in your externalized folder.

6. Start JAHIA

During the Jahia startup several scripts will be launched to migrate your data. One of them will migrate your repository from Blob to Datastore format. This operation can take some time depending of the size of your repository. To give you an idea 4Gb repository took 30min.

Please wait until the migration is completed.

For reference the last script to be executed is Execution of script ServletContext resource [/WEB-INF/var/patches/groovy/6.6.0.1-02-initialize-topic-sorting-date.groovy]

Your upgrade is now completed
patches.warning:
TO MIGRATE TO Jahia 6.6.X YOU WILL NEED TO HAVE A NEW LICENSE FILE.

Please contact your account manager before starting the migration.

During the Jahia startup several scripts will be launched to migrate your data. One of them will migrate your repository from Blob to Datastore format. This operation can take some time depending of the size of your repository. To give you an idea 4Gb repository took 30min.

patches.warning: Please make sure the db_script variable present in your jahia.properties reflect your database selection. If you upgrade from Jahia 6.5 it may still be set to db_script = hypersonic.script. The right value should be mysql.script, postgresql.script, mssql.script or oracle.script

$USER_HOME/.fixapplier/backup/ and a detailed log is also available in your <Jahia_installation>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/META-INF/updates/history/fixes/[PATCH].log or if you didn't use the default ROOT context in your <Jahia_installation>/tomcat/webapps/<your context>/META-INF/updates/history/fixes/[PATCH].log

If the fix creator detects that a file has been modified it will try to automatically merge it. If the merge fails you will be able to overwrite the files or skip it installing the modification. If the merge fails or you decide to skip it, a diff file <file_name>.patch will be available in the destination folder, please make sure that you don't forget to manually apply the changes.

1. Stop Jahia

2. Open a terminal in the JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/ROOT or JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/<your context> if you didn't use the default ROOT context  and type the following command:

java -jar <PATH-TO-FIX-APPLIER>/[PATCH].jar

The fix applier will manage the upgrade of your platform by deleting, updating and merging all the necessary files. It will now handles the migration of Jahia Core and all the additional Jahia modules installed on your platform.

In case you have externalized your configuration (jar file or folder), you will need to apply the modification relative to jahia.properties and jahia.advanced.properties manually at the appropriate place.

Please review your log before starting the next step to ensure you haven't missed a file that needs to be manually merged.

3. Clean the following Tomcat folder

The fix applier now handles the cleaning of the tomcat folders automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

Remove the content of your folders <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/temp and <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/work

4. Clean the ressource folder

Starting from 6.6.2.2  fix applier handles the cleaning of the /webapps/<your context>/resources folder automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

Remove the content of your folder  <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/resources or <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/webapps/<your context>/resources if you didn't use the default ROOT context.

5. Start JAHIA

Your upgrade is now completed

Please:

  • Stop the user requests / traffic to the server (either on the front-end Apache HTTPD server or firewall/router)
  • Stop Jahia before backing up and running the fix applier
  • Backup your Jahia installation before running the fix applier
  • Run a pre-production test first

patches.warning: In the current release we have fixed a security issue on tokenized form for allowing a token to be submitted only once so tokens are not reusable anymore. In order to be able to reuse token as it was before the release, we provided a property to set in the tokenizedForm tag: <template:tokenizedform allowsmultiplesubmits=true>. If you have already used this tag in your modules please review your implementation.

patches.warning:
In the current release, we :
  • Introduced a groovy script for cleaning up reference keeper nodes used by import/export service, it will be executed during first Jahia startup after migration and depending on your environmenet will take some times.
  • Fixed issue where a tokenized form could not be submitted in contribute mode right after content creation/deletion.For compatibility of form submission with contribute mode, if you are using a relative form action in your module that looks like:
    You should modify it to: Otherwise the URL will not work with contribute mode.
  • Added ability to return more than one spellcheck suggestion that introduced several modifications in SearchProvider interface, SearchService interface and Suggestion class. In case you have your own implementation of these provider or service, you need to take into account these last modifications.

patches.warning: Since version 6.6.2.5 we modified the way we were saving file links in richtexts by using the placeholder {workspace} in the url which is then dynamically interpreted in default and live workspaces instead of previous hard-coded values /live and /default. In the current release we introduced a migration groovy script which is executed at first startup after migration and corrects all existing links still containing these hard-coded values by replacing them with the new placeholder {workspace}. Depending on the volume of your data and the number of richtexts containing links, duration of this script's execution may vary.

  • Run a pre-production test first

For a standalone installation

Step 1:Jahia Core & Modules Migration

The first step of the migration is to copy the fix applier you would like to use on your production server.

At this stage, a list of all the files you have customized in your installation will help you to go through the upgrade and decide more easily if you want to merge, keep or overwrite the files.

For all the files impacted, the fix applier will create a backup in the following folder:

$USER_HOME/.fixapplier/backup/ and a detailed log is also available in your <Jahia_installation>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/META-INF/updates/history/fixes/[PATCH].log or if you didn't use the default ROOT context in your <Jahia_installation>/tomcat/webapps/<your context>/META-INF/updates/history/fixes/[PATCH].log

If the fix creator detects that a file has been modified it will try to automatically merge it. If the merge fails you will be able to overwrite the files or skip it installing the modification.

If the merge fails or you decide to skip it, a diff file <file_name>.patch will be available in the destination folder, please make sure that you don't forget to manually apply the changes.

1. Stop Jahia

2a. If you are upgrading your complete Jahia package :

Open a terminal in the JAHIA_INSTALLATION/ and type the following command:

java -jar <PATH-TO-FIX-APPLIER>/[PATCH].jar

If you use Digital Factory's configuration externalization:

----------------------------------------------------------------------

By default the FixApplier will try to look for an externalized configuration in the default location (tomcat/lib/jahia-config.jar). If you are not using the default location, you need to specify it on the FixApplier command line as in the following example:

	java -DalternateJahiaConfigPath=tomcat/jahiaConfig/org/jahia/config -jar Enterprise-DigitalFactory7.0-package_6.6.2.7_r50651_to_7.0.0.0_r49489.jar

In the above example the externalized configuration is inside an exploded directory tomcat/jahiaConfig. If you are using a JAR to store the externalized configuration (this is the default behavior), you need to specify the configuration location as in the next example:

	java -DalternateJahiaConfigPath=../../lib/jahia-config.jar!org/jahia/config -jar [PATCH].jar

The "!" (exclamation point) is used to specify a path inside the JAR file.

If you are using Digital Factory in a web context other than ROOT:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you have installed Digital Factory in another context than the default ROOT context, you will need to specify the directory location of the Digital Factory web application on the file system in a command line option, as in the following example:

	java -DwebappDirectory=tomcat/webapps/jahia -jar -jar [PATCH].jar

In the above example the "jahia" context has been used instead of the default ROOT context. Note that the web application could be located anywhere else, simply specify the directory in the command line property and the FixApplier will look for it in the specified directory.

2b. If you are upgrading your webapps :

Open a terminal in the JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/ROOT or JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/<your context> if you didn't use the default ROOT context  and type the following command:

java -jar <PATH-TO-FIX-APPLIER>/[PATCH].jar

The fix applier will manage the upgrade of your platform by deleting, updating and merging all the necessary files. It will now handles the migration of Jahia Core and all the additional Jahia modules installed on your platform.

In case you have externalized your configuration (jar file or folder), you will need to apply the modification relative to jahia.properties and jahia.advanced.properties manually at the appropriate place.

Please review your log before starting the next step to ensure you haven't missed a file that needs to be manually merged.

3. MySQL JDBC driver

In case you are using MySQL as a target DBMS, you need to manually install the MySQL JDBC driver, otherwise you can skip this step. Please download the mysql-connector-java-5.1.29.jar and copy it into your <jahia_installation>/tomcat/lib folder.

Note, please, that by using this driver, you are accepting the terms and conditions of the GPL License.

Remove the content of your folders <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/temp and <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/work

4. Clean the following Tomcat folder

The fix applier now handles the cleaning of the tomcat folders automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

Remove the content of your folders <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/temp and <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/work

5. Clean the ressource folder

The fix applier will also handles the cleaning of the /webapps/<your context>/resources folder automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

Remove the content of your folder  <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/resources or <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/webapps/<your context>/resources if you didn't use the default ROOT context.

6. Start JAHIA

Your upgrade to Digital Factory 7.0.0.0 in cluster is now completed.

If the fix creator detects that a file has been modified it will try to automatically merge it. If the merge fails you will be able to overwrite the files or skip it installing the modification.

If the merge fails or you decide to skip it, a diff file <FILE_NAME>.patch will be available in the destination folder, please make sure that you don't forget to manually apply the changes.

1. Stop Jahia

2. Open a terminal in the JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/ROOT or JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/<your context> if you didn't use the default ROOT context  and type the following command:

The fix applier will manage the upgrade of your platform by deleting, updating and merging all the necessary files. It will now handles the migration of Jahia Core and all the additional Jahia modules installed on your platform.

In case you have externalized your configuration (jar file or folder), you will need to apply the modification relative to jahia.properties and jahia.advanced.properties (or jahia.node.properties) manually at the appropriate place.

Please review your log before starting the next step to ensure you haven't missed a file that needs to be manually merged.

3. Clean the following Tomcat folder

The fix applier now handles the cleaning of the tomcat folders automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

Remove the content of your folders <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/temp and <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/work

4. Clean the ressource folder

Remove the content of your folder  <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/resources or <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/webapps/<your context>/resources if you didn't use the default ROOT context.

5. Start your JAHIA

6. Restart your JAHIA after re-indexation

At the end of the previous startup process, go to http://localhost:8080/tools/search.jsp and click on Repository re-indexing - Do repository re-indexing on the next Jahia start. Start your jahia again,it will perform a complete re-indexation.

Your Digital Factory upgrade is now completed.

patches.warning:
Starting from 7.0.0.2, jahia.advanced.properties is renamed to jahia.node.properties, all setting except cluster related ones are moved to the jahia.properties and only cluster setting is kept in jahia.node.properties which are now located in the new externalized configuration folder named by default digital-factory-config. Please make sure your settings are well transfered between these two files at the of migration procedure.

Starting from Digital Factory 7.0.0.2, the runtime data and main configuration files are by default located outside of the Digital Factory Web application (the feature, known previously as externalization). This allows for more clear separation of artifacts, better customization, production deployment and maintainability throughout the project life-cycle, including hot fixes and upgrades. By default the runtime data is saved in a new folder named digital-factory-data and the configuration in another folder named digital-factory-config. The FixApplier takes care of this modification during its execution.

patches.warning: After running the hotfix applier 7.0.0.3 and during the first start of Digital Factory right after, there could be errors reported, mentioning the unresolved constraints or missing dependencies in module. For resolving them when the startup is completely finished, please, verify that the modules are properly started and are in the Active state (either via Server Settings / System components / Modules UI or via Tools / OSGi console). If you have installed modules by uploading them to the server via module management UI (Server Settings) or by downloading them from a Private App Store (Available modules tab in the same Modules UI), you, most probably, will have to trigger the start of those modules manually after an upgrade. This is due to a slight difference in their deployment lifecycle, compared to modules, located in /modules folder. Please, use the Modules UI or OSGi Console to verify the status of those modules and to start them.

If you have installed Digital Factory in another context than the default ROOT context, you will need to specify the directory location of the Digital Factory web application on the file system in a command line option, as in the following example:

java -DwebappDirectory=tomcat/webapps/jahia -jar -jar Enterprise-DigitalFactory7.0-package_7.0.0.3_r51686_to_7.0.0.4_r51888.jar

In the above example the "jahia" context has been used instead of the default ROOT context. Note that the web application could be located anywhere else, simply specify the directory in the command line property and the FixApplier will look for it in the specified directory.

2b. If you are upgrading your webapps :

Open a terminal in the JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/ROOT or JAHIA_INSTALLATION/tomcat/webapps/<your context> if you didn't use the default ROOT context  and type the following command:

java -jar <PATH-TO-FIX-APPLIER>/<FIXAPPLIER_NAME>.jar

Then unzip this zip file containing 3-rd party licenses  into <digital-factory-home>/licenses/3rd-party folder.

The fix applier will manage the upgrade of your platform by deleting, updating and merging all the necessary files. It will now handles the migration of Jahia Core and all the additional Jahia modules installed on your platform.

In case you have externalized your configuration (jar file or folder), you will need to apply the modification relative to jahia.properties  jahia.node.properties manually at the appropriate place.

Please review your log before starting the next step to ensure you haven't missed a file that needs to be manually merged.

3. Clean the following Tomcat folder

The fix applier now handles the cleaning of the tomcat folders automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

Remove the content of your folders <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/temp and <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/tomcat/work

4. Clean the ressource folder

The fix applier will also handles the cleaning of the <JAHIA_INSTALLATION>/digital-factory-data/generated-resources folder automatically but depending on the OS and some permissions you may need to clean it manually.

6. Start your JAHIA

Your Digital Factory upgrade is now completed.
patches.warning: Please note that the following steps are for projets running under tomcat or Jboss. In case you are using Web Sphere please refer to the section 7 of 7.002 WebSphere 8.5.5 installation guide and at the end of the procedure and before stating the DF unzip this zip file (http://www.jahia.com/downloads/jahia/digitalfactory7.0.0/licenses-3rd-party.zip) containing 3-rd party licenses  into <digital-factory-home>/licenses/3rd-party folder.
